clues.text: To produce those charming smiles, these were generally cleaned with a green hazel twig
These fairs held in the Champagne area included annual ones for cloth & leather
The Duke of Apulia first issued this coin in the mid-1100s; the clue here is "Duke"
In the 1122 Concordat of Worms, Henry V gave up the right to appoint these church leaders
At the turn of the 13th century, St. Francis of Assisi & this Spaniard founded friar movements
Often fitted with glass, it's an opening in a ceiling to let the sunshine in
It's the combined structure atop a church that includes the tower & spire
A style of window popular in commercial buildings of the 1890s is named for this Illinois city
Architect Sir John Soane's eccentric home in this capital city features mock ruins & an Egyptian crypt
N. Hawksmoor assisted John Vanbrugh in designing this palace for the Duke of Marlborough
It's the English title of the ever-popular Mozart opera "Le Nozze di Figaro"
"Nothung! Nothung!" is Siegfried's song about his sword in this composer's opera "Siegfried"
This ragtime composer's opera "Treemonisha" is about a baby found under a tree by a woman named Monisha
A soprano plays the role of the Sandman in this 1893 Humperdinck opera
This "Peter and the Wolf" composer was only 9 when he wrote his first opera, "The Giant"
Countries bordering on this gulf include Qatar & Saudi Arabia
The Bay of Tangier on Africa's northern coast is an inlet of this strait
During WWI 2 famous battles took place near this longest tributary of the Seine
Lisbon lies on this river, the longest on the Iberian Peninsula
Noted for its high tides, this bay separates Nova Scotia from New Brunswick
She first told the tale of Peter Rabbit in a letter to her former governess' son
This author of "The Age of Innocence" was born Edith Newbold Jones in 1862
Flannery was this "Wise Blood" author's middle name; her first name was Mary
This author of "The Thorn Birds" published "The First Man in Rome", a historical novel, in 1990
"The Sisters Rosensweig" is a recent play by this writer of "The Heidi Chronicles"
Of all birds, they're the most fully adapted to water... & ice
It's considered the largest songbird, & you can "quoth" me on that
In relation to its size, this flightless bird of New Zealand lays the largest eggs
Once hunted for its plumes, the egret belongs to this family of long-legged wading birds
It's any of 3 cranelike birds of South America, or a North American swan named for its loud cry
Susan Watson played teen Kim MacAfee on stage & she played the role in the 1963 film

"Gray skies are gonna clear up"—do this; "brush off the clouds and cheer up"—do this

Birdie's first name... we love it!
Before he became Cuba's current leader, he defended the politically oppressed as a lawyer
He was a lawyer before he teamed with Arthur Sullivan in 1871
In 1969 this lawyer became the first Philippine president to win a second term
With only about a year of law school, this "Kingfish" passed the Louisiana Bar Exam in 1915
In the 1890s this Indian was admitted to practice before the South African Supreme Court
In 1930 the name of Turkey's capital was officially changed from Angora to this
Popular Turkish foods include mutton, rice, yogurt & this dish of meat & vegetables on a skewer
Late astronaut James B. Irwin led several expeditions to this Turkish mountain in search of Noah's Ark
A basilica near Ephesus houses the traditional tomb of this apostle & gospel writer
After this empire's demise in 1922, Turkey became a republic
On Dec. 10, 1520 he publicly burned a copy of a papal bull; he was excommunicated a month later
1 of his personas on "Saturday Night Live" was Katharine Hepburn's cousin Nelson, a hot dog vendor
U may not know that Martin Klaproth discovered this radioactive element in 1789
While in the White House, he created the Blue Room by having some crimson furniture reupholstered
From 1938-1945 Texas congressman Martin Dies, Jr. served as the first chairman of this infamous committee
clues.response: The House Committee on Un-American Activities

rounds.comments: (Alex: Boy, are we trying hard on this one.)

clues.text: These part-leonine beasts built their nests from gold; Merv might be interested

As the porter of Heaven, he opened the year, so our first month is named for him
She left Menelaus for Paris—the man, not the city

One of this "Little Rascal"'s last appearances before his death in 1993 was a cameo on "Cheers"

From 1968-1981 this former defense secretary was president of the World Bank

rounds.text: Chapter 100 of this novel introduces the one-armed Captain Boomer of the Samuel Enderby
